results.title: Hospital accident prevention: how to survive the working day
results.creator_credit: Don Charlton, Consort Films and Brent Walker Film Productions
results.brief_description: A safety film on hospitals. Hospitals are unique in many aspects, and an unusual guided tour highlights the risks, risk areas and their special hazards. Safety procedures are explained and the way to avoid accidents diagnosed. Peter Sallis (portraying the safety officer) and Fred, the cartoon character explore the hospital. Fred finds out for himself that if safety rules are ignored in one deparment, innocent people in another can and do get hurt!
results.title_for_label: Hospital accident prevention: how to survive the working day
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Charlton, Consort Films and Brent Walker Film Productions

results.title: Hospital [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Since the 1960s Frederick Wiseman has been at the forefront of the direct cinema documentary movement. Interrogating the public and social institutions of the United States he has built up an acclaimed oeuvre which has greatly influenced filmmakers around the world. In “Hospital” he worked with the doctors, staff and patients of New York City’s Metropolitan Hospital Centre. Wiseman’s commitment to the aesthetics of cinema-verite means that there is no narration or exegesis in his film practice. Instead, the camera becomes an observer of the pressures and crisis of a public hospital in the USA. What emerges is a portrait of a public institution stretched to the limits and a damning condemnation of poverty in America. “Hospital” allows us to observe all aspects of hospital life: well-meaning but seriously over-worked doctors and psychologists; nurses and attendants; cleaners and ambulance workers. And finally there are the patients themselves. Whether their illnesses are due to drugs or alcohol, to old age and over-work, or to violence and accident, what we get to witness is the pressure of survival for people who live at the bottom of the American social order.

results.title: Hospice
results.brief_description: This film is about a new concept in caring for the terminally ill. Staff members explain how they help their patients on a day-to-day basis, trying to make life for the patient as easy as possible, free of physical and emotional pain, and with constant care attention given in a home-like atmosphere.

results.title: Horses, riders, successes: German equestrianism today
results.brief_description: In Germany a large proportion of the horse population is employed in industry, agriculture, and in breeding, whereas the number of horses used for sport is by comparison small. The chief breeding areas are near Hanover, in Oldenberg, Westphalia, and Schleswig-Holstein. Breeding and sport often combine. Shows the work, training and successes of German horsemen.

results.title: Horses
results.creator_credit: Justin Milne and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basics to Eventing”.
Horse riding and good horsemanship in three parts. Pt. 1: “The Ten Commandments” gives an introduction to the basics of good riding. Pt. 2: “Learning to Jump” shows the way in which horses and riders are trained for jumping in the South Australian Police Force Mounted Division. Pt. 3: “The Cross-Country Event” focuses on differing aspects of horsemanship from handling to competition.

results.title: Horsemen of the Pampa (Argentina)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Life in Argentina. The story centres around a gaucho and his son, who are seen in typical surroundings carrying out their daily activities and enjoying home life at night

results.title: Horse talk
results.creator_credit: Paul Barralet and Paul Barralet Productions
results.brief_description: The various ways in which the horse still plays an active part in British life. Dray horses, horses on the farm, thoroughbreds and ponies for sport, and many others. The ceremonial horse being trained for the intricate pattern of ancient customs and great occasions which are part of Britain’s tradition. Commentary by James McKechnie.
